Notice: This material may be protected by copyright law (Title 17, U.S. Code)
J. Am. Ceram, Soc., 71 [8] 666-72 (1988)
Sol-Gel Synthesis of Magnesium Oxide-Silicon Dioxide Glass Compositions
NAROTTAM P. BANSAL*
Lewis Research Center. National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Cleveland, Ohio 44135
MgO-SiO2 glasses containing up to 15 mol% MgO, which could not have been prepared by the conventional glass-melt- ing method because of the presence of stable liquid-liquid im- miscibility, have been synthesized by the sol-gel technique. The gelling time decreased with increase in magnesium con- tent, water: TEOS ratio, and reaction temperature. The gels were subjected to various thermal treatments and character- ized using DTA, TGA, IR spectroscopy. XRD, and surface- area- and pore-size-distribution measurements. No organic groups could be detected in the glasses after heat treatments to == 800℃, but trace amounts of hydroxyl groups were still present. The overall activation energy for gel formation in the 10MgO - 90SiO: (mol%) system for the water: TEOS mole ratio of 7.5 was calculated to be 58.7 KJ/mol.
1. Introduction
GLASS compositions within the stable liquid-liquid immisci- bility region cannot be prepared by the conventional glass- melting method. However, such glass compositions may be obtained by the sol-gel technique using metal alkoxides and metal salts as the starting materials. The free energy of a gel is higher' than that of the glass of the same composition. It

+45 g of SiOC,H.12. 80 ml of C;H.OH. and 19.5 g of water.
should. therefore, be possible to convert a gel into glass at tem- peratures much below the liquidus temperature. The sol-gel technique has become quite popular"-19 during the past few years. It has been used for the preparation of glasses, fibers, protec- tive and other coatings, optical films, ultrapure monosized fine ceramic powders. composite materials, etc. Oxide glasses. including those of the CaO-SiO2. SrO-SiO2, and ZrO ;- SiO; systems, which are difficult to make by melting, have been syn- thesized11-1' by the sol-gel procedure.
The present study was undertaken with the primary objective of synthesizing MgO-SiO2 glasses containing various concentra- tions of MgO within the stable liquid-liquid immiscibility com- position range by the sol-gel technique. Another purpose of this work was to prepare compositionally homogeneous precursor ma- terials for use in studies of the effects of microgravity on phase separation in glasses. Gels of different compositions in the binary MgO-SiO2 system were synthesized under various experimental conditions, subjected to different thermal treatments, and charac- terized using a number of techniques. The results of these investi- gations are reported in this paper.
II. Experimental Methods
(1) Gel Synthesis
Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS)," Si(OC;Hs).," Mg(CH,COO);" 4H.O .* Mg(NO;); " 6H.O.' and 200 proof absolute ethyl alcohol were used without further treatment. Magnesium ethoxide is eas- ily available but has only limited solubility in alcohol. Therefore, the method of Mccarthy and Roy16 was employed to incorporate magnesium oxide into the gel. Mg(NO3) . 6HO was chosen as the source of magnesium oxide because of its good solubility in alcohol and in water. A similar approach has also been adopted by other workers11-14.17.18 to introduce other metal oxides into the gels in the form of their soluble metal salts.
The chemical compositions of the glasses used in this study and their symbols are shown in Table 1. Figure 1 is a partial phase diagram of the MgO-SiO; system showing that the compo- sitions of this study are in the liquid-liquid immiscibility dome.
The procedure used for glass synthesis by the sol-gel process follows. Mg(NO2),.6H2O was dissolved in alcohol and mixec under stirring with TEOS which had been diluted with alcohol The quantities of the various chemicals used are listed in Table I. Alcohol acts as the mutual solvent for TEOS and water, which are

miscibility, have been synthesized by the sol-gel technique.

were subjected to various thermal treatments and character-

area- and pore-size-distribution measurements. No organic

to == 800℃, but trace amounts of hydroxyl groups were still
present. The overall activation energy for gel formation in the
10MgO - 90SiO: (mol%) system for the water: TEOS mole
ratio of 7.5 was calculated to be 58.7 KJ/mol.

MgO-SiO2 glasses containing up to 15 mol% MgO, which could not have been prepared by the conventional glass-melt- ing method because of the presence of stable liquid-liquid im- miscibility, have been synthesized by the sol-gel technique. The gelling time decreased with increase in magnesium con- tent, water: TEOS ratio, and reaction temperature. The gels were subjected to various thermal treatments and character- ized using DTA, TGA, IR spectroscopy. XRD, and surface- area- and pore-size-distribution measurements. No organic groups could be detected in the glasses after heat treatments to == 800℃, but trace amounts of hydroxyl groups were still present. The overall activation energy for gel formation in the 10MgO - 90SiO: (mol%) system for the water: TEOS mole ratio of 7.5 was calculated to be 58.7 KJ/mol.

GLASS compositions within the stable liquid-liquid immisci- bility region cannot be prepared by the conventional glass- melting method. However, such glass compositions may be obtained by the sol-gel technique using metal alkoxides and metal salts as the starting materials. The free energy of a gel is higher' than that of the glass of the same composition. It

It has been used for the preparation of glasses, fibers, protec- tive and other coatings, optical films, ultrapure monosized fine ceramic powders. composite materials, etc. Oxide glasses. including those of the CaO-SiO2. SrO-SiO2, and ZrO ;- SiO; systems, which are difficult to make by melting, have been syn- thesized11-1' by the sol-gel procedure.

The present study was undertaken with the primary objective of synthesizing MgO-SiO2 glasses containing various concentra- tions of MgO within the stable liquid-liquid immiscibility com- position range by the sol-gel technique. Another purpose of this work was to prepare compositionally homogeneous precursor ma- terials for use in studies of the effects of microgravity on phase separation in glasses. Gels of different compositions in the binary MgO-SiO2 system were synthesized under various experimental conditions, subjected to different thermal treatments, and charac- terized using a number of techniques. The results of these investi- gations are reported in this paper.

Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS)," Si(OC;Hs).," Mg(CH,COO);" 4H.O .* Mg(NO;); " 6H.O.' and 200 proof absolute ethyl alcohol were used without further treatment. Magnesium ethoxide is eas- ily available but has only limited solubility in alcohol. Therefore, the method of Mccarthy and Roy16 was employed to incorporate magnesium oxide into the gel. Mg(NO3) . 6HO was chosen as the source of magnesium oxide because of its good solubility in alcohol and in water. A similar approach has also been adopted by other workers11-14.17.18 to introduce other metal oxides into the gels in the form of their soluble metal salts.

The chemical compositions of the glasses used in this study and their symbols are shown in Table 1. Figure 1 is a partial phase diagram of the MgO-SiO; system showing that the compo- sitions of this study are in the liquid-liquid immiscibility dome.

The procedure used for glass synthesis by the sol-gel process follows. Mg(NO2),.6H2O was dissolved in alcohol and mixec under stirring with TEOS which had been diluted with alcohol The quantities of the various chemicals used are listed in Table I.
